etymologies: mid 16th century: from medieval Latin qualificatio(n-), from the verb qualificare (see qualify)

definitions: a pass of an examination or an official completion of a course, especially one conferring status as a recognized practitioner of a profession or activity

examples.text: I left school at 15 with no qualifications

shortDefinitions: pass of examination or official completion of course

definitions: the action or fact of becoming qualified as a recognized practitioner of a profession or activity
shortDefinitions: action or fact of becoming qualified as recognized practitioner of profession or activity

definitions: a quality or accomplishment that makes someone suitable for a particular job or activity

examples.text: only one qualification required—fabulous sense of humour

shortDefinitions: quality or accomplishment that makes someone suitable for particular job or activity

definitions: a condition that must be fulfilled before a right can be acquired; an official requirement

examples.text: the five-year residency qualification for presidential candidates

shortDefinitions: condition that must be fulfilled before right can be acquired

definitions: the action or fact of qualifying or being eligible for something

examples.text: they need to beat Poland to ensure qualification for the World Cup finals

shortDefinitions: action or fact of qualifying or being eligible for something

definitions: the qualification stage of a sporting event

examples.text: he played a big part in the qualifications because he scored nine goals

definitions: a statement or assertion that makes another less absolute

examples.text: this important qualification needs to be remembered when interpreting the results
I welcome without qualification the Minister's statement

shortDefinitions: statement or assertion that makes another less absolute

definitions: the attribution of a quality to a word, especially a noun.
